Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Elucidating the molecular mechanism of the Vibrio cholerae Vc2 cyclic di-GMP riboswitch

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: A fundamental decision faced by all organisms is whether to colonize a given environment or migrate to new a one. For bacteria, this decision consists of transitioning between a motile state, and a sessile, biofilm forming existence. Biofilms are defined as multicellular communities of bacteria that are encased in a protective extracellular matrix. Biofilms are the predominant form of bacterial growth in nature, and allow bacteria to survive predation, toxic chemicals, and harsh conditions. Thus, biofilms represent important ecological niches in every environment and influence industrial applications such as agriculture, bioenergy and water purification. Over the last decade, it has become apparent that the intracellular signaling molecule cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP) plays a fundamental role in the vast majority of bacteria to control the transition between motility and biofilm formation. However, the molecular mechanisms by which c-di-GMP regulates these behaviors are not well understood. This research project will study a novel mechanism by which c-di-GMP exerts its function. In Vibrio cholerae, c-di-GMP binds to a conserved RNA structure called a riboswitch. Riboswitches traditionally function by controlling the expression of the downstream gene on the same RNA segment. In V. cholerae, this riboswitch is designated as Vc2. However, preliminary experiments suggest that binding of c-di-GMP to Vc2 actually increases the stability of an upstream small RNA (sRNA), which then appears to impact bacterial behaviors. This project will focus on how (a) binding of c-di-GMP to Vc2 stabilizes the traget sRNAs; (b)the Vc2 target genes are regulated; and (c) the Vc2 RNAs impacts the biology of the bacterium. This research is likely to uncover a novel genetic regulatory mechanism that governs the transitioning between distinct phases of biofilm formation. Moreover, discoveries from this project will inspire new approaches to cultivate beneficial biofilms while inhibiting harmful ones.

Broader Impacts: This project will also serve as a platform to broadly engage members of the academic community and the general public in scientific education and discourse. During the period of this award, undergraduate and graduate students in an upper level microbiology course (Microbial Genetics) and in the investigator's laboratory will be taught and mentored to become highly trained members of the future scientific community. The investigator will also initiate a number of activities to further engage the general public such as the organization of an annual "Microbiology Day" at "Impression 5" science center located in Lansing, MI. The investigator will also develop and teach a continuing education program titled "Hot Topics in Sciences" as part of the Evening College curriculum at MSU. This class will provide adults from the local community with the scientific principles behind a number of controversial science topics prevalent in the public consciousness. The project team will also instruct local high-school science teachers about microbial biofilms in the MSU "Frontiers in Science" program. Finally, the research team will train underrepresented students recruited from the Summer Research Opportunities (SROP) program offered by Michigan State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major challenges faced by bacteria is how to sense, respond, and appropriately adapt to an ever-changing environment. Unlike our own cells, which live in relatively unchanging conditions, bacteria can experience dramatic shifts in temperature, salinity, pH, or threats from predators and bacterial viruses known as phage. To survive all of these challenges, bacteria have mastered the ability to sense their local environment and express the appropriate genes to adapt to these challenges. My laboratory is interested in understanding how bacteria use chemical signals to carry out this environmental sensing, focusing on the human pathogen Vibrio cholerae. In addition to its impact on human health as the causative agent of the disease cholera, this bacterium must adapt to numerous environments including life in ponds and growth in the human small intestine, making it an ideal model system to study environmental adaptation.  

Although V. cholerae has several chemical signals that it uses for this, the focus of this research project was the chemical cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP). C-di-GMP is the key signaling molecule in bacteria that controls a shift from a sessile lifestyle as a multicellular biofilm to a motile, planktonic existence. In this grant, we studied one of the molecular mechanisms involved in this response, the Vc2 c-di-GMP binding riboswitch. Riboswitches are untranslated pieces of RNA that typically regulate the expression of the downstream gene in response to small molecular cues. In the case of Vc2, it was known that c-di-GMP binds to this riboswitch, but at the start of the project the impact of this interaction on the biology of V. cholerae was not known. I am happy to report that we have made great progress towards understanding this pathway.

Like the vast majority of riboswtiches, we found that Vc2 regulates the downstream gene, tfoY, in response to c-di-GMP. Specifically, we found that V. cholerae inhibits production of tfoY when c-di-GMP levels increase, although we have not yet elucidated the mechanism by which this occurs. Prior to the initiation of our studies, the function of tfoY had never been studied, but in an exciting result, we showed that the protein this gene makes induces a novel type of motility in V. cholerae. This result fits with the paradigm of c-di-GMP signaling as TfoY induces motility at low levels of c-di-GMP via regulation by Vc2.

In addition to its standard regulation of tfoY, we also discovered a completely novel mechanism of regulation driven by Vc2. We showed that binding of Vc2 to c-di-GMP leads to production of a small untranslated RNA (sRNA). sRNAs in bacteria often function as regulators themselves controlling the expression of additional genes. We demonstrated that binding of c-di-GMP to Vc2 prevents the sRNA from being degraded by enzymes that chew up RNA molecules called RNAses. We hypothesize this is because when Vc2 binds to c-di-GMP it forms a tight, compact structure that can block the activity of the RNAses. Thus, increasing levels of c-di-GMP leads to a novel sRNA that has a riboswitch bound to c-di-GMP on its end. In addition, binding of c-di-GMP to Vc2 inhibits TfoY expression. Therefore, the Vc2 riboswitch has two distinct functions when it binds to c-di-GMP. The major outcomes of this research are a better understanding of the role of c-di-GMP in allowing V. cholerae to adapt to its environment and the discovery of a novel mechanism of gene regulation.

This project supported the training and development of multiple graduate and undergraduate students, providing a pipeline of young scientists to enter the scientific community. During the course of this research, we also developed a ?Microbiology Day? at the Impression 5 Science Center at Lansing, MI. During this day, approximately 10 faculty assisted by multiple students presented hands on displays for the local community to learn about all aspects of microbiology including pathogenesis, antibiotic resistance, bioengineering, ecology, and evolution. We also organized and led a ?Microbe Magic? station at the annual Michigan State University Science Festival that had similar hands on exhibits. Finally, this grant supported multiple visits to local elementary science nights. During these events, we demonstrated bioluminescent bacteria and educated the public on the beneficial relationship of bacteria to their animal hosts.
